arm_group.description: Subjects will lie supine on a treatment table and receive a high velocity low amplitude thrust joint manipulation to their cervical spine in rotation to each side of the neck.
Subjects will lie supine on a treatment table and have their suboccipital region gently cupped by the therapist for 30 seconds. No movement or force will be applied, just simple manual contact.

brief_summary.textblock:
Cervical spine manipulation (CSM) is utilized by many health care practitioners in the
      management of patients with neck pain and headache. How CSM works is not understood however,
      most researchers agree that there is likely a combination of mechanical, neurophysiological
      and placebo effects. This study will test for possible neurophysiological effects by
      examining for changes in a person's ability to reposition their head and neck in space, and
      maintain their balance following CSM.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cervical Spine Manipulation Affects on Balance and Proprioception

detailed_description.textblock:
Consenting participants will have their proprioception tested through a joint repositioning
      error test for their cervical spine, and also have their balance tested through a Neurocom
      Balancemaster. Following these pre-intervention measures, they will receive in a random
      order, either a cervical spine manipulation (CSM) or a sham manipulation, and then have
      tests repeated to analyze for changes and differences between interventions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  healthy individuals between the ages of 18 and 60

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  current neck pain/symptoms; neck pain symptoms within the last 6 months; confirmation
             or possibility of pregnancy; dizziness; vertigo, or nausea;  history of cervical
             spine surgery; rheumatoid arthritis; osteoporosis; osteopenia; ankylosing
             spondylitis; cancer; or vertebral artery insufficiency.

facility.name: Department of Physical Therapy, University of Nevada Las Vegas

clinical_study.official_title: Immediate Effects of Cervical Spine Manipulation on Balance and Joint Proprioception in Healthy Individuals

other_outcome.description: Subjects stand on a force plate on a SMART Neurocom Balance Master and complete a Sensory Organization Test (SOT) program which assesses somatosensory, visual and vestobular systems used in maintaining balance.

primary_outcome.description: Subjects wear a headband with a mounted laser pointer and sit 1 meter away from a wall. They assume their comfortable neutral cervical posture and then close their eyes and extend their cervical spine and return to their neutral posture with eyes closed. The laser pointer marks the point of return and we measure the difference between start and end points for error.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
